Posts.Content: Hi Mandymoo76, I agree that the waiting time is absolutely awful and it sounds as if yours has been prolonged.  I was warned by my Consultant that sometimes biopsies need repeating for the reason you mentioned.  I'm usually so patient but I think I would be making a few ripples by now.  Watch the signs of depression, perhaps see the gp.  You need to be mentally fit for the fight ahead.  I get my biopsy results today and I'm not mentally fit at this point... Take care xxx
Posts.Title: What are you supposed to do? :(

Posts.Content: I'm a 38jj and haven't had surgery yet.  I have bought some crop top sleep bras from Evans online which fit well and provide good support.  For the daytime I've bought non wired bras from Bravissimo online.  They said that if I have a mastectomy they offer a service to sew pockets in any of their bras whatever size.  I hope that helps. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Mastectomy bras for big boob

Posts.Content: Hi, I agree as I wanted to spend the Summer in Crete!  Never mind xxx
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Just an update - I managed a whole day without any tears yesterday and I've woken up feeling more Optimustic.  I caught myself thinking 'when this is over I'm going to....' Which is the first time that's happened as I was stuck in dark thoughts that this will never be over.  I'm proud of myself and long may it continue! Thanks for all your support. Jo xx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Morning ladies, I've woken up this morning with a new attitude and I'm not sure where it's come from.  Over the past month I've gone from blind panic to deep sadness.  Yesterday I felt very low as I missed out on all the Christmas celebrations at school and it was my first Christmas as head.  I've been moping around, having my 20minutes crying each day and generally being miserable and focusing on worst case scenarios.  Today I've decided that I'm fed up with being miserable and it isn't helping anyone.  I'm going to focus on a positive outlook until someone tells me otherwise. I'm going to be thankful that the chemo was relatively kind to my body,  I'm going to believe that the chemo is doing its job even if I can't feel it and I'm going to give my children and husband a 'normal' Christmas.  All the negativity can go in a box until the 30th when I get my scan results and see the oncologist.  I think that People with 2 x grade 3 lumps, possibly no node involvement, have survived this horrible disease and so can I.   I really hope I can continue with this thought over Christmas.  Jo xx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Hi, just curious - anyone who's had chemo first - how long did you have to wait for surgery after the end of chemo?  And then how much gap between surgery and radiation?  Many thanks. Jo x
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks Jilly, to good to hear that you're reaching the end of chemo.  It still seems a long way off for me! I hope it goes well xxx
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Thank you - I have my boxing gloves on! Xx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Thank you, that really helps xx
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, I am planning that party!  My husband just mentioned the Bahamas too!  Xx
Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Thinking of you Ronstar xxx
Posts.Title: Just so fed up - will it ever end?

Posts.Content: Thanks Wendy. Prior to all of this I was a very upbeat, positive person so I've been really surprised by my response.  The last two days have been much better and I'm beginning to convince myself that there's every chance I can beat this.  I have to as there's no alternative as I have two beautiful children.  Have a wonderful Christmas. Jo xxx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Sorry you experienced this.  I hope it's better tomorrow but keep us posted xx
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Ronstar, I hope you're ok and not it too much pain X
Posts.Title: Just so fed up - will it ever end?

Posts.Content: Fantastic news xx
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass, it might be best to seek information sooner than the 17th, that way you won't have it playing on your mind.  Perhaps contact the surgeon via his/her secretary to ask the question.  Don't let it spoil your previous weekend. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Who would you contact?

Posts.Content: Hi, does anyone have any experience of high glucose readings following chemo?  My pre surgical assessment last Tuesday registered my blood glucose as high.  My surgeon did a finger test pre surgery which was still high but he didn't seem worried.  I've just added my practice nurse to check and it's still high.  I've researched to see that chemo and steroids can trigger diabetes.  I've lost loads of Weight during chemo.  Diabetes is not a chemo gift that I want to be left with!  Any experience? Jo X
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thanks Toxophilite.  I'm hoping it's just short term then.  My gp wants me to go for a glucose tolerance test next week (not that they will be able to get any blood out of me!).  He wants to stabilise it in the short term to give my body chance to recover.  I know it's only a small thing but I'm fed up.  I don't want diabetes long term.  I suppose it's a small price to pay but up until last November I was really well! X
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thank you, that's really helpful.  It seems like it's trial and error.  I will asked about the Hba1c test too. Thanks jo x
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: I will be thinking of you tomorrow.  Everyone has already said everything that I would want to say.  You are a fabulous role model to us all. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn, that's helpful x
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thanks JMC04.  I'm hoping it's a temporary thing and will resolve when things settle down.  I was just fed up because it's another thing but then again at least I'm alive to endure diabetes.  X
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn, I have no symptoms at all other than a high glucose reading.  I've finished chemo so no more steroids so I'm hoping I can control it with diet and exercise but my gp is keen to stabilise it first.  I also lost weight during chemo.  Diabetes is in my family so I was expecting it eventually but I've been eating so healthily and lost weight so it's frustrating that it's arrived now.  I've heard that a low carb diet is the key. X
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thanks Grogg.  I eat a lot of fruit...
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn, my dad has the testing kit but doesn't really use it so I may steal it.  I had a look at the GI index and cross referenced to the type of foods I eat.  I've been eating low carbs and eating about 8 portions of f&v a day, but quite a bit of fruit.  It's a good point about combining foods rather than eating them in isolation.  Xx
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Good news. Glad it's sorted. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Angry over sick note

Posts.Content: So today I am 44 years old.  The 'gifts' I experienced today were: A complete meltdown at 7.30 that it was my birthday and the multi agency team were meeting today to decide on what I have and what is going to happen to me A call to the Macmillan nurse who reassured me that there would be a course of treatment for me, the 5cm tumour and 2cm tumour weren't the end of everything and there is hope. Another meltdown that if I have chemo it may not work and then I'm left with nothing Another meltdown that there wouldn't be any mastectomy bras or inserts for a 38JJ cup A final meltdown where I was convinced everything would have travelled round my body by now. Then I remembered that my real gifts were: Gorgeous cards and pressies from my lovely husband and boys 4 birthday cakes A lovely Chinese takeaway An evening spent with my family, (punctuated by trips to the toilet for meltdowns) Not the best birthday I've every had by any stretch of the imagination but I am blessed with things that have nothing to do with my current situation.  Now to steel myself for my appointment on Wednesday. I then remember that all of these meltdowns are based on a very incomplete picture and we don't even know what we are dealing with apart from that 'it's big and looks very suspicious but the armpit looks clear'.
Posts.Title: Birthday

Posts.Content: Emma, I found it tougher but definitely manageable.  One more to go... Xx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Hope you are doing ok Scotty66. Enjoy the birthday celebrations. Jo x
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Fabulous news xxx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: I'm desperate to feel some shrinkage!  I am booked for a scan after my 3rd and 6th chemo. X
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Fabulous news xx

Then I remembered that my real gifts were: Gorgeous cards and pressies from my lovely husband and boys 4 birthday cakes A lovely Chinese takeaway An evening spent with my family, (punctuated by trips to the toilet for meltdowns) Not the best birthday I've every had by any stretch of the imagination but I am blessed with things that have nothing to do with my current situation.  Now to steel myself for my appointment on Wednesday. I then remember that all of these meltdowns are based on a very incomplete picture and we don't even know what we are dealing with apart from that 'it's big and looks very suspicious but the armpit looks clear'.

Posts.Content: Thank you Helen, i do too! Xx

Posts.Content: Thanks all, just been Christmas shopping so now to wrap everything in sight! Xx
Posts.Title: Birthday

Posts.Content: I've switched to non-wired bras as well Carolyn.  Was a big step for me and there's not much choice but I was pleasantly surprised.  I got a couple from Bravissimo and they support me just as well.  I've now lost a stone and a half so will need to changed them soon.  My boobs are shrinking quicker than my lump! X
Posts.Title: Bras again!

Posts.Content: I had the same experience.  No pain at all n the arm with T. Xx
Posts.Title: Arm pain after Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Gill, sorry to hear that your still experiencing pain.  I haven't taken any pain relief.  I get the odd twinge but nothing major.  I had the dressing changed on Monday.  I didn't want to look but she said the scars were very neat and there were no signs of infection.  I'm going tomorrow to have the steri strips removed.  My bruising has almost gone and I'm very pleased that there's no sign of a dent or any change in size or appearance.  I did have a lot of breast tissue though as I'm very large chested!  I am very achy but I think that's still the after effects of chemo.  I also have tingling in 3 fingers that I didn't have after chemo.  It was my whole hand straight after surgery but it is slowly getting better.  Have you had chemo as thus may be affecting how you are.  Maybe the pain is worse now as all the nerves are knitting back together.  I can definteky feel more twinges now rather than straight after surgery.  When are your results?  Mine are next Wednesday.  Really hoping there's no more surgery needed.  Hope your pain eases soon. Jo x
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Good idea to take the wires out - I have a couple of brand new bras I could do that to. Xx
Posts.Title: Bras again!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, it was 10 days ago now.  Was expecting my dressings off today but the nurse said a tiny corner hasn't healed yet so she put another steri strip on and I have to go back on Tuesday.  Results on Wednesday x
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Many thanks Coastal-lady.  I'm going to make the most of a good rest! X
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Sounds like you're having a tough time. The difference might also be the location.  My WLE is very close to the SNB scar.  If yours was near the nipple that's more of your breast affected.  It might also be more sensitive in that area.  I hope you get on ok tomorrow.  Are you expecting results to be back? X
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Good luck and let us know how you get on xx
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: I'm so sorry that the pain is affecting you in this way. I have nothing to offer you other than the fact that I'm thinking of you and you aren't alone.  If the gp types tomorrow when you're speaking I suggest you ask her to stop - not a good way to deal with people. Take care. Jo xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Now that really is good news - sleep really makes all the difference xx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: so my surgery was fine yesterday - anyone waiting for a WLE and SNB please be reassured.  They lost my notes so everything was delayed until 4 so I just sat on my own in a room waiting.  They didn't allow companions.  The guided wire was fine as was my radioactive injection.  Went down at 4 and they were all lovely.  Woke up at 8 because they needed me to leave!  Home 8.30 virtually sleep walking, straight to bed!  No pain relief needed so far.  Daren't look to see what's there.  I didn't see a doctor before leaving but my discharge letter says they got both tumours as one sample and they took my sentinel node. xxx
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Thank you. She said I can start the exercises later this afternoon..  Movement is good so far though!
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Gill, I'm so sorry that the results weren't as you would have hoped.  Does it mean that you have to have more surgery?  I'm glad your arm us feeling better today. Jo x
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: Thank you.  I hope the second surgery goes well.  Keep us posted xx
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: I'm permanently attached to my iPad looking at this site. It really helps me.  My husband commented on it quite a bit at the start but he hasn't for ages.  I can't focus on the tv anyway. Julia has given some good advice - someone to talk to would be good.  Xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: I found the helpline inabluable when I was first diagnosed.  No idea if they knew what I was saying as I was sobbing so much.  Take care xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: Sounds like you're having a tough time.  It's very stressful for you all and it's bound to come out somehow.  Talking is good as everyone reacts differently when under pressure. Take care xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: Hi, sorry that you have something else to worry you.  I haven't had surgery yet so I can't offer any advice other than I'd speak to your medical team - they are the only ones who can offer reassurance.  I'm thinking of you xx
Posts.Title: upper back pain

Posts.Content: Really good to hear that you're feeling a bit better.  Lovely news xxx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: Me too LondonLass. Thinking of you today x
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi, worried 2016.  I'm so sorry that you are having a tough time.  It's is the hardest time isn't it.  I think that you anxiety and questions are also normal.  I can empathize entirely with the panic attack situation.  Remember that every woman is different and reacts differently.  There are no rules here at all it seems!  Just remember that there are people here who can help you through it and answer your questions. xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: email me if you need me whilst you're locked out of messenger! I thought the dye was just to signify where the nodes were - then they remove them and test them under microscope hence the wait.  But I may be completely wrong!  I don't think reconstruction is needed if only a small area of tissue is  removed.  Keep calm and breath deeply xxxx

Posts.Content: LondonLass, you give so much to other people. I agree that you are a fantastic role model to us us newbies.  This just makes you more so.  Big hug to you xxxx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi, quick question.  I've heard that there are two types of T drug - one for node positive and one for node negative.  Has anyone else heard that?  Ultra sound and ct scan saw nothing under my arm and my oncologist write Axilla negative on all letters but I'm aware that this can't be guaranteed until I've had surgery.  How do they know which T drug to give me?  I would hope they'd give me the one that assumes it's positive until proven otherwise.  Not seeing oncologist for 2 weeks so thought I'd ask you. Thanks jo X
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: In terms of genetics I don't think I'll even get the test as apart from an aunt there is no history in my family. X
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you.  I start the T in 2 weeks and my genetics appointment is in April!
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you all.  I'm having the 3 weekly drug and you have reassured me - thank you.  Scan this week to see if it's shrinking so think of me on Thursday! Xxx
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo

Posts.Content: I'm not very domesticated mistymoley!  I think I'll rely on M&S....
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: So after having two 'brave'days today has been a bit difficult again.  It started off well, meeting some very kind friends for coffee.  I had a dental check up for pre chemo.  My dentist is lovely so as soon as I saw him I cried all over him.  He then said that he wanted to make sure everything was fine before chemo so sent me to the hospital for a full jaw scan.  Terror started - if you've seen my earlier posts you will know that scans and results are currently terrifying me.  Any way queued at the x ray department and cried the whole time.  back to dentist and no treatment needed.  cried again.  Got home exhausted and not having eaten all day.  The hospital phoned to say my oncologist wanted me to have an ultrasound tomorrow.  Panic again!.  Asked what it was for and she said 'marker clip insertion'.  I've heard it is no worse that the biopsy- is it painful?  Quick?  Jo x
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: That must have been so hard Wombat 23.  I only had 3 months off for maternity leave so this is going to be so hard.  Thinking of you too xx
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: Hi, I've only had one FEC so far so I can't give you any tips but I just wanted to say I hope the next one us better. Jo xx
Posts.Title: FECing Veins!

Posts.Content: That's strange as both my children are at my school and my husband teaches there too.  I'm pleased because I know they will be well looked after.  SLT know but I'm telling staff in briefing tomorrow.  I will be asking then to be careful talking about it because I want to protect my boys.  I'm not telling parents as I hope to work remotely so there is no need for them to know yet.  My son is in Year 11 - his mocks started today.  xx
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, that's a good tip.  It's all starting now xx
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: I will be thinking of you tomorrow.  You can do this xx
Posts.Title: Here goes...first day of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, I did look thank you. Just had 3 hours sleep which was good but now I'm in panic mode.  The middle of the nights are awful.  The what ifs are terrible and it seems that won't end on results days - then there will be the results of Mri, surgery, further scans etc.  I just need to know what I'm dealing with and hope that I can deal with it.  Thank you for sharing with me Xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Also, your description of what you experienced is really helpful.  I'm genuinely not worried what treatment plan they aim for, just so long as there is one...reading the posts I think mastectomy is preferable to several smaller ops that need repeating.  Do you get the results of Mri on the same day or is it more waiting? Sorry for questions x
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Hi JM.  Hope you are coping.  Have you organised a wig?  It's on my growing list of things to do... xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi, not yet.  Marker clip tomorrow, oncologist Friday so I should know more then.  I've bought 3 beanie hats but that's it.  I need to get moving! X
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Thank you Carolyn. It's Good to hear from someone who also had such a large lump as it has been panicking me.  I appreciate your response xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Ejm60, I agree the forum is fantastic.  Sounds like you're having a tough time and sensible to take something.  Was doing fine this morning until I took my dressing off from my biopsy.  I'm convinced it's grown and far too big for them to treat.  I'm angry at myself that I didn't feel it sooner and feel that I've brought this on myself.  Anger is an understatement.  Take are xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Thanks Grogg, the biopsy didn't hurt so that's reassuring. x
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: All done.  The only thing that hurt was the injection from the local.  Now feel I am on the way to starting which means my fight can start.  I also told staff at school today. Standing up in front of 300 people and saying I have breast cancer was the hardest thing I've ever done but people have been great - caring but discrete. Thank you all for your kindness - you make me feel calmer xx
Posts.Title: What a day...Marker Clip Insertion

Posts.Content: How naive am I - I forgot about other areas of body hair!  I have hairy arms so looking forward to that going! xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: So no sleep last night, panicked all day then strangely calmer this evening.  Now just got in bed and the terror has arrived again.  I've convinced myself that because I have very very large breasts (38jj) I didn't find my lump until it was at least 6cm and that means that it will be the very worst news.  US can't see anything in LN but I'm now panicking over that and what may be revealed in surgery.  I really want to get off this roller coaster.
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Going public is going to be hard I think. I've just started as headteacher of a large secondary school. Dream job....I find this site so comforting but I'm slightly addicted - like I'm clinging to something. X
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: You've had a lot to put up with. The same back to you - I'm here to respond if you need to talk X
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Toxophilite, now that really isn't fair!  X
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi, feeling better today.  just had the marker clip inserted which was fine but cried all the way home.  My husband was fascinated by the ultra sound and watching the clip being inserted - typical man.  oncologist tomorrow so I should have more of an idea then.  the consultant radiologist said she would scan me after the 3rd cycle and 5th cycle and I wasn't to panic if there was no shrinkage immediately - some women don't get shrinkage until right at the end.  Hope you are coping with chemo xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Thank you for the warning - it helps. I have one that is over 5cm and that has panicked me beyond belief but it's better during the day xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: I went last week too.  Lovely to get beautiful freebies and people were very kind.  It would be good if they could source some paraben free stuff as there's quite a bit I can't use.  My friends were happy though!
Posts.Title: Look Good Feel Better courses

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, I've been worried about this. I'm having chemo first in the hope of shrinking my lump ready for a WLE but if this doesn't work I was worried about mastectomy, not for fear of losing my breast but of being lopsided.  I'm a 38jj (but I've lost a stone since my dx so probably a bit smaller).  My bmi is over 30 but I'm very active and I think in proportion(!) but from what you've said I'd probably wouldn't be offered recon.  I'm not worried about being flat but If I was losing one breast it would probably help my balance to lose the other one too but I doubt they'd agree to that for that reason.  I have plenty of time to research and to watch what happens to my lump but it is something that's been playing on my mind.  Jo xx
Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, you're right.  Thinking positive is the key I think xx
Posts.Title: I'm not allowed reconstructive surgery because my BMI is to high

Posts.Content: Lovely to hear some good news x
Posts.Title: Gene test result :-)

Posts.Content: I'm not sure what type of cancer counts.  The questionnaire will tell them what they need to know xx
Posts.Title: Genetics

Posts.Content: Hi loulou99, I had my first dose last week and was very nervous but it was fine.  Definitely not as bad as I anticipated and I recovered quickly.but everyone responds differently.  As Julia said, drinking lots of water really helps and I took every tablet I was given and avoid sickness and nausea.  Listen to your body and rest when needed but a good walk helps too.  I'm not nervous about dose 2.  Please ask if you have any questions at any time. Jo xxx
Posts.Title: Fidst chemo session tomorrow

Posts.Content: Cocopops, I've been referred for this but I'm fully anticipating that they won't test me.  The only history is my maternal aunt (dx aged 44 died aged 49) breast cancer and my grandad (stomach cancer in his 80s).  They wouldn't test my friend and her mother also had breast cancer. Jo x
Posts.Title: Genetics

Posts.Content: Thinking of you LondonLass xx
Posts.Title: 2hrs Sleep....

Posts.Content: Happy Birthday LondonLass xx
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Thank you - that's really helpful.  Xxx

Posts.Content: Morning, just had a call from the hospital. Panic because I thought it was to say there was an issue with my bloods.  The nurse due to do my pre chemo assessment is poorly so they've moved it to the hour before chemo starts tomorrow.  I understand completely but just thought I'd ask you all my question.  Is there anything that I need to be doing today in preparation?  Anything useful that she might have told me? Thanks in advance. Jo x
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: M blood pressure was off the roof! Hope it will come down soon! Xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi, I bought a thermometer but nothing on blood clots.  She's going to meet me an hour earlier tomorrow.  I had height, weight and bloods done on Friday but not blood pressure.  I imagine that will be sky hi!, just made up my mouthwash and having lunch with my hubby xx

Posts.Content: Thank you - that's really helpful.  Xxx

Thanks in advance. Jo x
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hi, I bought a thermometer but nothing on blood clots.  She's going to meet me an hour earlier tomorrow.  I had height, weight and bloods done on Friday but not blood pressure.  I imagine that will be sky hi!, just made up my mouthwash and having lunch with my hubby xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: M blood pressure was off the roof! Hope it will come down soon! Xx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Alison, congratulations on your last day of radiation xxx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic, I am experiencing a very similar diagnosis.  I'm downstairs pretending that everything is ok but when I'm on my own I'm a wreck.  My husband says he will surgically remove my iPad as I'm not spending time with them! I'm constantly on the forum, partly to look for people with a similar diagnosis who are doing so well and coping with treatment, and partly because I don't feel so alone when I'm on this forum.  I haven't started treatment yet so that is worrying me (I'm being unreasonable here as I was only diagnosed on Wednesday!). Having chemo first then surgery. Everyone responds differently and you are experiencing shock.  I've experienced a roller coaster of emotions and there have been moments when I've forgotten completely but then it hits me again.  You are going through a terrible time but you can do it because you have to for your beautiful family.  I'm here if you need me. Jo xx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Well done!  I think the fear of spread is a constant one but we have to deal with what we know now and your scans were clear.  I'm so good at advice - I wish I listened to myself though! Take care and try to enjoy your evening with your lively family xx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: It will be up and down. I'm having an up time tonight but when I'm down I'm sure everyone will be there. That's why this site is so important.  Xx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Lovely!
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Baki, I can't even begin to imagine what you're feeling tonight so I just wanted to send you a hug and to let you know that I'm thinking of you.      Jo xxx
Posts.Title: Guilt and Self loathing

Posts.Content: Take each day as it comes.  You haven't had the results from surgery yet.  You need to focus on recovering so that you are well enough to begin chemo if that's what's advised.  My consultant said that there have been lots of studies about the impact of positive thinking on outcomes.  He really believes it makes a difference.  Strong and determined is the key.  It's like a battle and we need to have the boxing gloves on.  Remember though, you are not alone in the battle - use us if you prefer to protect your family.  I'm here. Jo xxx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: morning Optimustic, how are you doing this morning? Xx
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: Hi, sorry that you're having a tough time.  I'm glad the enlarged lymph has been checked for you as that's reassuring for you.  It's not surprising that your bp is high at the moment.  Mine was through the roof at my first chemo so they gave me a tablet which relaxed me.  The district nurse checked it the next day and it was within normal limits again.  I think I have white coat syndrome.  The tablets will do their job for you so try not to worry as it will be counter productive.  I'm not sure what the oncologist meant by chemo not being a cure etc.   I would ask your bcn as it will worry you which you don't need at the moment.  Take care. Jo xxx
Posts.Title: Any advice

Posts.Content: I'm thrilled for you - congratulations. Jo xxxxx
Posts.Title: Positive point 6!!!!!!

Posts.Content: My eyes are worse too.  Had a debate with some savers as I don't want my eye test and contact lense check until everything settles x
Posts.Title: Repeat eyetests

Posts.Content: Fabulous news!  I'm really pleased for you.  I never thought a month ago I would be so pleased that someone could have chemo!! Jo xx
Posts.Title: All clear for the second FEC-T tomorrow.

Posts.Content: I'm so pleased that you got to spend time with your family yesterday.  I hope the journey home isn't too bad xxx
Posts.Title: Hoping everyone is enjoying the holiday.

Posts.Content: hi everyone.  I had my first T last week.  I think I have very mild palmers planter syndrome on my hands.  They are a little red and feel like the skin is tight.  I phoned the chemo unit today and they just said to use moisturiser and phone if my hands swell.  No sign of that.  Tried to take my rings off just in case but there's no way my wedding ring is budging. I'm not in pain at all, it's just a little uncomfortable and isn't getting worse.  I've read that it can cause chemo to be delayed or the dose reduced.  I definitely don't want this to happen.  Does anyone have experiencec of this? Thanks Jo
Posts.Title: Palmer Planter Syndrome

Posts.Content: Oh dear, that doesn't sound good.  I'm deaf in one ear and have no balance.  I usually trip up the stairs, usually in front of lots of children at school!  Hope you don't feel too sore tomorrow xx
Posts.Title: went flying...

Posts.Content: Hi misteymoley, no it wasn't him, he'd never behave like that.  It was the doctor doing the ultrasound.  He could have prevented a complete meltdown if he'd just explained what my bcn did afterwards!  She was excellent x
Posts.Title: Why do I feel so inadequate.

Posts.Content: Don't stop getting things checked out.  I've had a few appointments recently with medical professionals who don't seem to like human beings.  My doctor today who did my scan sat with his back to me while I asked questions. He was typing at the same time.  Led to a massive meltdown.  I was told off last week for wanting things to happen to quickly.  Some emapthy would be good sometimes.  Xx
Posts.Title: Why do I feel so inadequate.

Posts.Content: Excellent news xxxx
Posts.Title: More shrinkage on 'T' chemo.

Posts.Content: Well done, that's a massive achievement xx
Posts.Title: Back to work - another box ticked

Posts.Content: I've not gone on there as I would be too scared to know. I don't know for certain that I have no lymph node involvement until surgery (after chemo) so I don't have a full picture yet.  I also don't know my Her2 status yet.  I think I'm going to stay clear of statistic as if I've learnt anything in the last 3 weeks it's that every one is different and everyone responds differently.  I did look at some on CRUk and they were based on one town in the uk between 2002-2006! On the other hand perhaps they aren't as bad as I'm already imagining in my head! Take care xx
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Fabulous news xx
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Worried 2016, I'm thinking of you today.  The advice here has been excellent.  I phoned the macmillan nurse yesterday and she was amazing.  Very calm and reassuring.  I am imagining all sorts of aches and pains too so I think that's normal.  Thank goodness for people on this site who can help you with deciphering the diagnosis.  take care xxxx
Posts.Title: A million questions and worries.....anxiety attack ?

Posts.Content: Evening all, I have grade 3 IDC TNBC and am currently having FEC-T (second dose done) followed by surgery and rt.  I'm 44 and my maternal aunt died of BC in the 1980s.  I have no idea what type of bc she had but she was diagnosed at 44 and died at 49.  That is the only history of cancer in my family that I'm aware of.  My oncologist has referred me for genetic testing.  Does anyone know what the test is? Does it hurt?  How long did you wait to be seen and get the results?  Ideally I'd like results prior to surgery so that if it's positive I can have everything at once.  If it's positive what does that mean?  Any information would be appreciated as I don't want to google. Thanks jo xx
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: Thank you Fiddlercrab, that's helpful Jo x
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, that's really helpful. Jo xx

Posts.Content: That would be good! X
Posts.Title: Genetics testing

Posts.Content: I've just finished it and I'm inspired!  I've had my 5 portions of f&v today but wasn't up to too much activity.  X

Now that is something to be proud of.  Take care xx

Posts.Title: Ever so slightly stunned ! Please not again.

Posts.Content: I've just had the worst conversation with my 15 year old son. He asked me if I have breast cancer. I didn't realise but our iPads are linked and my google search history came up on his device. I'm devastated. He's in the middle of his mock exams and I didn't want to ruin his childhood just yet. I've been economical with the truth and said I found a lump and that I've had it tested but I'm waiting to find out what it is. I've said that I'd probably have to have a small op to remove it and said that I'm not worried so he shouldn't be. Now I'm being overly bright and breezy but screaming inside. This is horrendous. Google, for a number of reasons, has not been my friend.
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: I know Crystal juju, you're right.  I just wanted the treatment plan before I told him. I was hoping that I'd be able to leave it until his Mock exams finished.  He seems ok and is sitting downstairs watching the football rather than lounging in his room which is lovely!  Xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn.  I'm his headteacher and my husband also teaches at the school so I'm confident he'll be well loved.  We also gave a school counsellor who will support him.  I just wanted to wait until I knew what was going to happen and he'd finished his mocks.  I can't believe your son's school reacted like that. Shocking xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Wow, you've dealt with a lot.  He has reacted very well and seems ok.  I've told him to ask me any questions that that I will tell him what they say to me on results day next week.  I will keep him in the picture as I can see where you're coming from.  But I will be relentlessly positive in front of him - he deserves a mum who fights! Xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Alison, the distraction makes sense.  At least I will be home more to monitor his revision! X
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Carolyn, we have an excellent pastoral team and a school counsellor.  We have a referral system so that if we spot anything amiss we can intervene and offer support.  We have several children who have cancer as well as some who have parents facing it.  My children are lucky to be surrounded by such wonderful adults in our school but I know that some schools focus on nothing but academic.   We know our children and know when something isn't quite right. Jo X
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Worried 2016 That sounds like a good strategy you used with your son.  I'm beginning to think I've played it down too much now. Although I have said we will know much more on Wednesday so I can share more then.  He seems ok and I've told him to ask me any questions.  He asked if it hurts.  Worrying about him has distracted me from worrying about me ( until bedtime) xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Welcome x
Posts.Title: Hi Spudzmum and Melancholy

Posts.Content: Carolyn, my son has just said the same thing when I asked him if he was ok 'you told me not to worry so I'm not worrying'.  I love my job so will be desperate to get back to it.  Need to get through it all for so many reasons xx
Posts.Title: Children

Posts.Content: Carolyn, I think a bit of both.  It would be good if your son's got any advice.  I've told him mostly the truth - I said small lump (rather than big lump), I said the doctors are testing it to see exactly what it us and that I'm likely to have an operation.  I didn't say that the consultant was certain it is cancer.  That can wait until Wednesday when I can tell him the next steps.  The relentlessly positive aspect is about making sure that he knows I can beat this.  It sounds like the strategies you mention are really positive xx

Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hi, glad to hear you are feeling positive.  Sounds like you've had a good day.  I wish I could focus on the positives as you suggest.  I've just been out with friends for a curry and it was awful.  I just wanted to run.  I'm terrified and keep thinking that my cancer isn't contained within my breast (the US didn't reveal any concern under my arm but that's not 100%) and I'm terrified that the chemo won't work on my tumour.  My husband said that I need to focus on the fact that my consultant said it was very treatable but it's so hard.  I just want to start so that there is less chance of it spreading.  I'm getting very good at acting and pretending everything is ok!  Xxx

Posts.Content: Sounds like a rubbish say.  Hope tomorrow is better xx

Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: I have 2. Before chemo started they were 4.5 and 2.4.  They didn't feel like lumps though, more of a thickening.  I have large breasts so it took longer for me to find them - I checked my breasts religiously.  Chemo is shrinking them well. Jo X

Posts.Content: Hi cocopops I'm on 3 weekly T but my face went quite red last night.  It's gone today though. Hope you are ok. Jo x

Posts.Title: Panic setting in before operation

Posts.Content: That's good to hear JMC04.  I've developed a sharp pain in my arm today when I stretch.  I think it may be my veins protesting from chemo.  Poor anaesthetist trying to get a vein tomorrow! Xx
Posts.Title: Panic setting in before operation

Posts.Content: Hi optimistic, I am in a state of panic tonight too - mostly to do with fear of spread and the possibility that chemo might not work. My husband says that I must focus on the positives rather than what I don't yet know but it's so hard.  I offer this just so that you know you are not alone xxx
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: Thank you all.  I'm still surprisingly calm.  I just want it done now xx
Posts.Title: Panic setting in before operation

Posts.Content: Hi  I'm just at the very beginning of this journey and I'm a 38 JJ.  Although it was the first question my consultant asked me, My size hadn't occurred to me in term of the implications afterwards - thank you as you have enabled me to think this through and have the right questions prepared.  Thank you xx
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I finished treatment on the 19th June 2017 for grade 3; stage 2b TN BC - two lumps.  I had FECT, lumpectomy (clear nodes) and 15 rads.    I returned to work full time the day after and have got on with my life. Just before dx I started my dream job as a headteacher and I managed to work through treatment with reduced hours.  I’m fitter, healthier and thinner than I’ve ever been.  I have finally achieved a healthy work life balance and spend lots more time with my family.  BC was a horrible shock and a really difficult time but for me it really was the wake up call I needed to really change my life.  This forum was a life saver in the early days and I still pop in for a visit now and then to see how people are doing.  I’m on holiday this week in a very wet Wales so have had time to read more posts.  So apart from the odd worry worms about recurrence I can really say that I am feeling really good.  If you’re just starting out then I can remember how you are feeling and it does eventually come to an end.  Then it’s time to live your life again and make the most of every moment. With best wishes to you all. Jo x
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Sounds like you’ve had a tough time but glad that you are still so positive xx
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic, good to hear from you and that you are ok.  The emotional battle seems harder that the chemo battle in some ways xx
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Thanks Londonlass.  We are definitely making the most of things.  We cancelled a family holiday to New York last Christmas due to chemo so we are trying again this Christmas (I won’t let my husband book anything but flights and hotel until after my mammogram next month).   The the two of us are going to the Bahamas at Easter.  My boys are upset that we haven’t invited them! Take care. Jo x
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Little Lizzy, on this day last year I was diagnosed.  Some of the ladies on here will remember the frenzy I spun myself into.  I was out of control.  They calmed me down and were superb.  I can honestly say today I feel healthier and more positive than I ever have.  I am living every moment of my life and appreciating every second.  Nothing stresses me any more (except waiting for my results this week!) you will regain control and there’s is light at the end of the tunnel.  Stick with it and you’ll get there. Jo x
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi, worried2016, been thinking if you too - I read your earlier post. Sounds like you had a tough day.   I went to school and was very professional, talking to parents and listening to staff talking about their stresses.  Everything was an act and my smile fixed.  Left early as wanted to scream.  My biopsy was Tuesday morning so still saw as I had 2 samples taken with what seemed like a gun.  They are having the multi agency meeting tomorrow and I get the results on Wednesday.  It's my birthday tomorrow and I can't believe they will be deciding my fate on the day of all days!  Take care xx
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: Little-lizzy, it’s such a tough time but you will find a direction.  We all have something to offer it’s just had to find out what.  Being with children all day keeps me grounded and focused.  It offers a great distraction from thinking about myself! X
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Thanks Karen, I never thought that I would when I look back to the early days!  I hope you are well too. Jo x
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: I was only thinking about you the other day Janette.  I’m so pleased by your news.  I got my first year mammogram results today and it was all clear.  My doctor was really positive for the future as well.   Today is a really good day xxx
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hoping for some reassurance. I'm 43. I'm fixated on the size of my lump. I have one at over 5cm and one at 2 cm. Nothing seen under the armpit on ultrasound. Waiting for biopsy results. I'm convinced my lump is growing (rationally it is probably bruised from the biopsy). I'm convinced the news will be terrible next Wednesday due to size and they won't offer treatment. I'm ready to fight anything but what if they say it's too big to do anything about. I can't speak to anyone else about these fears as I feel it is all my fault. I check my breasts regularly but thought it was just the ligaments in my very large breast hardening as they travel south. I'm a 38 JJ. I went to doctors when I felt the lump but I've obviously missed for ages as its so big. It isn't really a lump but an oblong. Now I'm feeling all sorts of aches and pains that weren't there two days ago. The wait is awful. I can't think of anything else and trying to be normal around my children is so hard. Thank goodness for you all xx

Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi, how many days did the worst of it last?  Any other side effects other than joint pain?  I'm having T for my last 3 doses. Thanks Jo x
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry, I finished chemo in March.  For me T was a completely different experience to FEC, not worse, just completely different.  No nausea and the side effects are delayed by a few days.  I had a terrible taste in my mouth for about 10 days.  I experienced leg pains and achy feet too.  My feet still ache now at night.  None of it is pleasant but now I've completely finished treatment and beginning to get my life back again it is all beginning to fade.  Good luck. Jo x
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Morning.  It's natural to be terrified.  I was a wreck before my first chemo and they had to give me medication to calm me down.  I'm going for number 3 this morning and not worried at all.  Everyone is different with side effects but your doctor will do everything possible to minimise them and you will be reviewed each time.  It is definitely doable and it doesn't last forever, just a few days.  You will get through it and your inner strength will come through.  Jo xx
Posts.Title: so scared new to this

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia. Last FEC and half way!  Really pleased x
Posts.Title: so scared new to this

Posts.Content: Fabulous news xx

Posts.Title: Job lot
